factoid: Sónya shook off some down that clung to her.
Sónya tucked away the verses in the bosom of her dress close to her bony little chest.
Sónya ran after Natásha down the passage into the sitting room.
Sónya had a flushed face.
Sónya had light, joyous steps.
The visitors requested the young people to sing the quartet "The Brook".
The young people sang the quartet "The Brook".
Everyone was delighted by the performance of the quartet "The Brook".
Nicholas sang a song he had just learned.
Nicholas had not finished the last verse before the young people began to get ready to dance in the large hall.
The sound of the feet was heard from the gallery.
The sound of the coughing of the musicians was heard from the gallery.
Pierre was sitting in the drawing room.
Shinshín engaged Pierre in a political conversation.
Pierre was a man recently returned from abroad.
Several others joined the political conversation.
The political conversation bored Pierre.
The music began.
Natásha came in.
Natásha walked straight up to Pierre.
Natásha laughed and blushed.
Natásha said, "Mamma told me to ask you to join the dancers."
Pierre replied, "I am afraid of mixing the figures."
Pierre replied, "but if you will be my teacher."
Pierre lowered his big arm.
Pierre offered his arm to Natásha.
While the couples were arranging themselves and the musicians were tuning up, Pierre sat down with Natásha.
Natásha was perfectly happy.
Natásha was dancing with a grown-up man.
The grown-up man had been abroad.
Natásha was sitting in a conspicuous place.
Natásha was talking to the grown-up man like a grown-up lady.
Natásha had a fan in her hand.
One of the ladies had given Natásha the fan.
Natásha assumed a pose of a society woman.
Natásha talked with her partner.
Natásha fanned herself.
Natásha smiled over the fan.
The countess exclaimed, "Dear, dear! Just look at her!"
The countess crossed the ballroom.
The countess pointed to Natásha.
Natásha blushed.
Natásha laughed.
Natásha said, "Well, really, Mamma! Why should you? What is there to be surprised at?"
In the midst of the third écossaise, there was a clatter of chairs being pushed back in the sitting room.
The count and Márya Dmítrievna had been playing cards with the majority of the more distinguished and older visitors.
The count and Márya Dmítrievna stretched themselves after sitting so long.
The count and Márya Dmítrievna replaced their purses and pocketbooks.
The count and Márya Dmítrievna entered the ballroom.
Márya Dmítrievna came first.
The count came next.
Both had merry countenances.
The count offered his bent arm to Márya Dmítrievna.
The count drew himself up.
A smile of debonair gallantry lit up the count's face.
The last figure of the écossaise ended.
The count clapped his hands to the musicians.
The count shouted up to the gallery.
The count addressed the first violin.
The count said, "Semën! Do you know the Daniel Cooper?"
The écossaise was the count's favorite dance.
The count had danced the écossaise in his youth.
Daniel Cooper was a figure of the anglaise.
Natásha shouted, "Look at Papa!" to the whole company.
Natásha bent her curly head to her knees.
Natásha made the whole room ring with her laughter.
Everybody in the room looked with a smile of pleasure at the jovial old gentleman.
The jovial old gentleman was standing beside his tall and stout partner, Márya Dmítrievna.
The jovial old gentleman curved his arms.
The jovial old gentleman beat time.
The jovial old gentleman straightened his shoulders.
The jovial old gentleman turned out his toes.
The jovial old gentleman tapped gently with his foot.
The jovial old gentleman's smile broadened his round face more and more.
The jovial old gentleman prepared the onlookers for what was to follow.
The provocatively gay strains of Daniel Cooper began to sound.
The doorways of the ballroom were suddenly filled by domestic serfs.
The domestic serfs were men on one side and women on the other.
The domestic serfs had beaming faces.
The domestic serfs had come to see their master making merry.
The nurse loudly remarked, "Just look at the master! A regular eagle he is!"
The nurse stood in one of the doorways.
